facts: The first program many programmers write is simply one that prints 'Hello, World!' on the screen.
The term "bug" in programming dates back to 1947 when a moth was found causing problems in a computer at Harvard.
The Python programming language is named after the British comedy series "Monty Python's Flying Circus," not the snake.
Ada Lovelace is considered the first computer programmer; she wrote an algorithm for Charles Babbage's early mechanical computer.
There's a programming language called Whitespace that uses only spaces, tabs, and newlines for its syntax.
NASA's Apollo Guidance Computer, which helped land astronauts on the moon, had less computing power than a modern smartphone.
LOLCODE is a programming language inspired by the language of "LOLCats" internet memes.
The first high-level programming language, Fortran, was designed to automatically generate assembly code.
"Hackathon" is a portmanteau of "hack" and "marathon," where programmers work intensively on software projects over a short period.
Grace Hopper, known as the "Mother of Computing," developed the first compiler, which translates high-level language to machine code.
Java, originally called Oak, was renamed after the developers drank lots of coffee while brainstorming a name.
Linux, one of the most popular operating systems, was created by Linus Torvalds and is open-source, meaning its source code is freely available.
The "Y2K bug" was caused by programmers using two digits for the year in date formats, which led to fears of systems failing at the turn of the millennium.
Thereâ€™s a form of creative writing called "code poetry," where programming languages are used to write poems.
The first known video game, "Spacewar!," was created by MIT students in 1962.
As of 2024, JavaScript remains one of the most popular programming languages globally.
The concept of "null" in programming was invented by Tony Hoare, who later called it a "billion-dollar mistake."
The longest word you can type with just your left hand on a QWERTY keyboard is "stewardesses."
Malbolge is a programming language designed to be as difficult as possible to program in, taking two years to write the first valid program.
Cowsay is a program that generates ASCII pictures of a cow with a speech bubble, often used as a joke among programmers.
ASCII art, creating pictures out of text characters, has a long history in programming, especially in the command line.
Google's Go language, also known as Golang, was designed to be simple yet powerful, with fast compilation.
The "404 Not Found" error was named after a room at CERN where the original web server was located.
Many programming languages start arrays with an index of 0 instead of 1, a practice originating from C language.
CoffeeScript is a language that compiles into JavaScript and is known for making JavaScript easier to read and write.
BASIC, an early programming language, was designed to be simple enough for beginners, leading to its name "Beginner's All-purpose Symbolic Instruction Code."
Some developers practice "the streak," where they commit code to a project every day without missing a day.
The first website ever created is still online and was created by Tim Berners-Lee in 1991.
Pair programming is a technique where two programmers work together at one workstation, with one writing code and the other reviewing it in real-time.
"Rubber duck debugging" is a method where programmers explain their code to a rubber duck or other inanimate object to find errors.
